repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Municipal Development, and Urban
            Infrastructure Services Development Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The report concurs with the
            Implementation Completion (ICR) ratings on the Urban
            Infrastructure Services Development (UISDP) Project on a
            satisfactory project outcome, likely sustainability, and
            substantial institutional development impacts. Similarly,
            regarding ratings on the Municipal Development Project
            (MDP), it concurs on a satisfactory project outcome, and
            likely sustainability, and, upgrades the institutional
            development impact from modest to high. Experience with
            these projects highlight the following lessons: 1) Policy
            and programs should continue to focus upon urban services
            improvements, which local authorities and entities should be
            willing to implement and finance, if strengthened local
            credit markets are to be effectively established to work. 2)
            The market for local sub-sovereign credit may be shallower
            than commonly believed. 3) To be profitable and still
            affordable to the poor, local urban services must operate
            very efficiently in order to keep costs down.

6924446.trustfund:
TF036905-GUYANA - EL NINO EMERGENCY
            ASSISTANCE PROJECT,TF022472-PHRD-URBAN REHAB. & MGMT. PROJECT,TF029375-PHRD-SECOND MUNICIPAL
            DEVELOPMENT PROJ.,TF035159-PERU - URBAN REHABILITATION AND
            MANAGEMENT PROJECT,TF035375-COLOMBIA - MUNICIPAL DEVELOPMENT,TF037777-COLOMBIA - URBAN INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECT,TF039967-COLOMBIA-URBAN INFRASTRUCTURE
            SERVICES DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The project was satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, though with modest institutional
            development impacts, while both the Bank, and Borrower
            performances were also satisfactory. Lessons indicate that
            private sector financial intermediaries can be a source of
            municipal finance under the right conditions, for although
            the Territorial Development Bank (FINDETER), did manage to
            leverage a percentage of project costs from financial
            intermediaries, most of these were public-sector financial
            intermediaries; thus, it is expected that the follow-up
            operation will emphasize more on private-sector banks
            participation. However, given that private sector lenders
            need stronger initial guarantees for municipal loans, an
            over-dependence upon such guarantees should be avoided,
            rather the emphasis should be on financially stronger
            municipalities. Moreover, the role of the private sector in
            the provision of urban services should be integral to
            infrastructure investments, and, in addition, consideration
            by the Bank, and donors on the appropriate technology,
            should be carefully designed into the lending program.
            Experience suggests that private sector participation with
            water utilities require strong municipal commitments, and be
            a precondition to reach agreement on tariffs, and subsidy
            structures. Also reinforced is the need for a flexible
            framework regarding key activities, for a single consultant
            preparing each procurement package to improve consistency,
            and, for standardizing the use of financial models for the
            analysis of new private sector managed utilities.

5079077.trustfund:
TF036905-GUYANA - EL NINO EMERGENCY
            ASSISTANCE PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
In support of its decentralization
            policy the Government has launched the Municipal Development
            Program (MDP), which aims at improving municipal services
            and strengthening municipal institutions.  The MDP includes:
            (a) the implementation through the Financiera de Desarrollo
            Territorial (FINDETER) of a new sector lending policy based
            on more stringent criteria of financial and institutional
            project feasibility; (b) actions to strengthen regional
            agencies who help local governments formulate their
            investment and institutional development programs; (c)
            training of sector personnel; and (d) actions to enhance
            municipal revenues including the property tax.  The project
            supports the MDP through the following components:  (a) a
            line of credit administered by FINDETER to finance about 300
            subprojects to improve urban infrastructure and strengthen
            beneficiary local governments; (b) a program to strengthen
            FINDETER and develop its lending pipeline; (c) the
            development of sector training agencies and the delivery of
            a training program to sector staff; and (d) a program to
            update cadasters nationwide.

abstracts.cdata!:
In support of its decentralization
            policy the Government has launched the Municipal Development
            Program (MDP), which aims at improving municipal services
            and strengthening municipal institutions.  The MDP includes:
            (a) the implementation through the Financiera de Desarrollo
            Territorial (FINDETER) of a new sector lending policy based
            on more stringent criteria of financial and institutional
            project feasibility; (b) actions to strengthen regional
            agencies who help local governments formulate their
            investment and institutional development programs; (c)
            training of sector personnel; and (d) actions to enhance
            municipal revenues including the property tax.  The project
            supports the MDP through the following components:  (a) a
            line of credit administered by FINDETER to finance about 300
            subprojects to improve urban infrastructure and strengthen
            beneficiary local governments; (b) a program to strengthen
            FINDETER and develop its lending pipeline; (c) the
            development of sector training agencies and the delivery of
            a training program to sector staff; and (d) a program to
            update cadasters nationwide.
